question: Question 15 In the circuit, the present value of [latex] Z [/latex] is 1 . Neglecting the delay in the combinatorial circuit, the values of [latex] S [/latex] and [latex] Z [/latex], respectively, after the application of the clock will be

x & \oplus & x & = & 0 \\

x & \oplus & 0 & = & x

 [/latex] [latex]

Question 20 Which of the following complex functions is/are analytic on the complex plane?
solution:
[latex]
\begin{aligned}
& \text { Let us take }(a), \quad f(z)=z^{2}-z \\
& u+i v=x^{2}-y^{2}+i(2 x y)-x-i y \\
& \Rightarrow \quad u=x^{2}-y^{2}-x, V=2 x y-y
\end{aligned}
 [/latex] Now by [latex] \mathrm{C}-\mathrm{R} [/latex] equation, [latex] u_{x}=V_{y} [/latex] and [latex] u_{y}=-V_{x} [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \quad(2 x-1)=(2 x-1) [/latex] and [latex] -2 y=-(2 y) [/latex] i.e. C-R equation are satisfied.

question: Question 21 Consider the complex function [latex] f(z)=\cos z+e^{z^{2}} [/latex]. The coefficient of [latex] z^{5} [/latex] in the Taylor series expansion of [latex] f(z) [/latex] about the origin is _____ (rounded off to 1 decimal place).
solution:
[latex]
f(z)=\left(1+z^{2}+\frac{z^{4}}{\underline{2}}+\frac{z^{6}}{\underline{6}}+\ldots .\right)+\left(1-\frac{z^{2}}{\underline{2}}+\frac{z^{4}}{\underline{4}}+\ldots . .\right)
 [/latex] It is series is of even powers. [latex] \therefore [/latex] Coefficient of [latex] z^{5}=0 [/latex].

question: Question 22 The sum of the eigenvalues of the matrix [latex] A=\left[\begin{array}{ll}1 & 2 \\ 3 & 4\end{array}\right]^{2} [/latex] is _____ (rounded off to the nearest integer).
solution:
[latex]
\begin{aligned}
A & =\left[\begin{array}{ll}
1 & 2 \\
3 & 4
\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{ll}
1 & 2 \\
3 & 4
\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{cc}
7 & 10 \\
15 & 22
\end{array}\right] \\
\lambda_{1}+\lambda_{2} & =\operatorname{Trace}\\
& =22+7 \\
& =29
\end{aligned}
 [/latex]

question: Question 23 Let [latex] X(\omega) [/latex] be the Fourier transform of the signal, [latex] x(t)=e^{-t^{4}} \cos t,-\infty \lt  t \lt \infty [/latex]. The value of the derivative of [latex] X(\omega) [/latex] at [latex] \omega=0 [/latex] at is _____ (rounded off to 1 decimal place)
solution:
[latex]
\begin{aligned}
t x(t) & \rightleftarrows j \frac{d X(\omega)}{d \omega} \\
f(t) & =\frac{t x(t)}{j} \rightleftarrows \frac{d X(\omega)}{d \omega}=F(\omega) \\
\left.\frac{d X(\omega)}{d \omega}\right|_{\omega=0} & =\left.F(\omega)\right|_{\omega=0}=\text { area of } f(t) \\
& =\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \frac{t x(t)}{j} d t=\text { area of odd-function } \\
& =0
\end{aligned}
 [/latex] [latex]
\left[\begin{array}{l}
\because x(t)=\text { even-function } \\
\therefore \frac{t}{j} x(t)=\text { odd-function }
\end{array}\right]
 [/latex]

question: Question 24 The incremental cost curves of two generators (Gen A and Gen B) in a plant supplying a common load are shown in the figure. If the incremental cost of supplying the common load is Rs. 7400 per MWh, then the common load in MW is ____ (rounded off to the nearest integer).
solution:
[latex]
\lambda=7400 \mathrm{Rs} / \mathrm{MWhr}
 [/latex] [latex]
I_{C A}\left(P_{G A}\right)=\frac{2000}{100} P_{G A}+8000
 [/latex] [latex]
\begin{aligned}
I_{C B}\left(P_{G B}\right) & =40 P_{G B}+6000 \\
\lambda & =I_{C A}=I_{C B}=7400 \\
200 P_{G A}+8000 & =7400 \\
P_{G A} & =-600 \\
P_{G A} & \\lt0 \\
P_{G B} & =\frac{7400-6000}{40}=35 \\
P_{G A}+P_{G B} & =35 \mathrm{MW}
\end{aligned}
 [/latex]

question: Question 25 A forced commutated thyristorized step-down chopper is shown in the figure. Neglect the ON-state drop across the power devices. Assume that the capacitor is initially charged to [latex] 50 \mathrm{~V} [/latex] with the polarity shown in the figure. The load current [latex] \left(I_{L}\right) [/latex] can be assumed to be constant at [latex] 10 \mathrm{~A} [/latex]. Initially, [latex] \mathrm{Th}_{\mathrm{M}} [/latex] is [latex] \mathrm{ON} [/latex] and [latex] \mathrm{Th}_{\mathrm{A}} [/latex] is OFF. The turn-off time available to [latex] \mathrm{Th}_{\mathrm{M}} [/latex] in microseconds, when [latex] \mathrm{Th}_{\mathrm{A}} [/latex] is triggered, is _____ (rounded off to the nearest integer).

Question 26 Consider a vector [latex] \bar{u}=2 \hat{x}+\hat{y}+2 \hat{z} [/latex], where [latex] \hat{x}, \hat{y}, \hat{z} [/latex] represent unit vector along the coordinate axes [latex] x, y, z [/latex] respectively. The directional derivative of the function [latex] f(x, y, z)=2 \ln (x y)+\ln (y z)+3 \ln (x z) [/latex] at the point [latex] (x, y, z)=(1,1,1) [/latex] in the direction of [latex] \bar{u} [/latex] is
solution:
We know that: directional derivative of '[latex] f [/latex]' at [latex] P(1,1,1) [/latex] in the direction of [latex] \vec{a} [/latex] is given by [latex]
\begin{aligned}
\text { Directional derivative } & =\nabla f \cdot \frac{\hat{a}}{|\bar{a}|} \\
\nabla f & =\hat{i} \frac{\partial f}{\partial x}+\hat{j} \frac{\partial f}{\partial y}+\hat{k} \frac{\partial f}{\partial z} \\
\nabla f & =i \frac{5}{x}+j \frac{3}{y}+k \frac{4}{z} \\
(\nabla f)_{(1,1,1)} & =5 i+3 j+4 k
\end{aligned}
 [/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] Directional derivative [latex] =\overline{\nabla f} \cdot \frac{\bar{a}}{|\bar{a}|}=(5 i+3 j+4 k) \cdot \frac{(2 i+j+2 k)}{\sqrt{2^{2}+1^{2}+2^{2}}}=\frac{21}{3}=7 [/latex]

question:
Question 27 The input [latex] x(t) [/latex] and the output [latex] y(t) [/latex] of a system are related as [latex]
y(t)=e^{-t} \int_{-\infty}^{t} e^{\tau} x(\tau) d \tau, \quad-\infty \lt t \lt \infty
 [/latex] The system is
solution:
System will follow law of superposition. Therefore, system will be linear. Time-invariance check: [latex]
y\left(t-t_{0}\right)=e^{-\left(t-t_{0}\right)} \int_{-\infty}^{t-t_{0}} e^{\tau} \cdot x(\tau) d \tau
 [/latex] For input [latex] x\left(t-t_{0}\right) [/latex], output will be [latex]
y(t)=e^{-t} \int_{-\infty}^{t} e^{\tau} \cdot x\left(\tau-t_{0}\right) d \tau
 [/latex] Put [latex] \tau-t_{o}=k [/latex], then [latex] d \tau=d k [/latex] and for [latex] \tau=t, k=t-t_{0} [/latex] [latex]
\begin{aligned}
& =e^{-t} \int_{-\infty}^{t-t_{0}} e^{k+t_{0}} \cdot x(k) d k \\
& =e^{-t} \times e^{t o} \times \int_{-\infty}^{t-t_{0}} e^{k} \cdot x(k) d k=e^{-\left(t-t_{0}\right)} \times \int_{-\infty}^{t-t_{0}} e^{k} \cdot x(k) d k \\
& =e^{-\left(t-t_{0}\right)} \times \int_{-\infty}^{t-t_{0}} e^{\tau} \cdot x(\tau) d \tau
\end{aligned}
 [/latex] Since, [latex]
y(t)=y\left(t-t_{0}\right)
 [/latex] So, the system is time-invariant.

options.A: [latex] T_{1} [/latex] and [latex] T_{2} [/latex] are BIBO stable.
options.B: [latex] T_{1} [/latex] and [latex] T_{2} [/latex] are not BIBO stable.
options.C: [latex] T_{1} [/latex] is BIBO stable but [latex] T_{2} [/latex] is not BIBO stable.
options.D: [latex] T_{1} [/latex] is not BIBO stable but [latex] T_{2} [/latex] is BIBO stable.

question: Question 29 If the Z-transform of a finite-duration discrete-time signal [latex] x[n] [/latex] is [latex] X(z) [/latex], then the [latex] Z [/latex]-transform of the signal [latex] y[n]=x[2 n] [/latex] is

Question 30 A 3-phase. [latex] 11 \mathrm{kV} .10 [/latex] MVA synchronous generator is connected to an inductive load of power factor [latex] (\sqrt{3} / 2) [/latex] via a lossless line with a per-phase inductive reactance of [latex] 5 \Omega [/latex]. The per-phase synchronous reactance of the generator is [latex] 30 \Omega [/latex] with negligible armature resistance. If the generator is producing the rated current at the rated voltage, then the power factor at the terminal of the generator is
solution:
[latex] \mathrm{pF}=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}=30^{\circ} \text { lagging } [/latex] [latex] 
\begin{aligned}
E & =\sqrt{(V \cos 30+I R)^2+\left(V \sin 30^{\circ}+I X\right)^2} \\
E & =\sqrt{(V \cos +I R)^2+(V \sin +I X)} \\
\frac{11 \mathrm{~K}}{\sqrt{3}} & =\sqrt{\left(V \cdot \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right)^2+\left(\frac{V}{2}+524.86(5)\right)^2} \\
\left(\frac{11 \mathrm{~K}}{\sqrt{3}}\right)^2 & =V^2 \cdot \frac{3}{4}+\left(\frac{V}{2}+2624.319\right)^2 \\
\left(\frac{11 \mathrm{~K}}{\sqrt{3}}\right)^2 & =\frac{3}{4} V^2+\frac{V^2}{4}+2624.319 \mathrm{~V}+2624.319^2 \\
V_t & =4618.105 \mathrm{~V} \\
(I Z)^2 & =E^2+V^2-2 E V \cos \delta \\
(2624.319)^2 & =\left(\frac{11 \mathrm{~K}}{\sqrt{3}}\right)^2+(4618.105)^2-2\left(\frac{11 \mathrm{~K}}{\sqrt{3}}\right)(4618.105) \cos \delta \\
\delta & =20.96 \\
\mathrm{pF} & =\cos (20.96+30)=0.629 \text { lagging }
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 31 For the three-bus lossless power network shown in the figure, the voltage magnitudes at all the buses are equal to 1 per unit (pu), and the differences of the voltage phase angles are very small. The line reactances are marked in the figure, where [latex] \alpha, \beta, \gamma [/latex] and [latex] x [/latex] are strictly positive. The bus injections [latex] P_{1} [/latex] and [latex] P_{2} [/latex] are in pu. If [latex] P_{1}=m P_{2} [/latex], where [latex] m > 0 [/latex], and the real power flow from bus 1 to bus 2 is 0 pu. then which one of the following options is correct?
solution:
[latex]
\begin{aligned}
P_{1} & =m P_{2} \\
P_{1} & =\frac{1 \times 1}{\beta x} \sin \theta \\
P_{2} & =\frac{1 \times 1}{\gamma x} \sin \theta \\
\frac{1 \times 1}{\beta x} \sin \theta & =m \frac{1 \times 1}{\gamma x} \sin \theta \\
\frac{1}{\beta} & =\frac{m}{\gamma} \Rightarrow \gamma=m \beta
\end{aligned}
 [/latex]

Question 33 Let [latex] f(t) [/latex] be a real-valued function whose second derivative is positive for [latex] -\infty \\lt t \\lt\infty [/latex]. Which of the following statements is/are always true?
solution:
[latex]
f^{\prime \prime}(t) > 0
 [/latex] If [latex] t \in(-\infty, \infty) [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow f(t) [/latex] is a parabola open upwards. So, it has only one minima at its stationary point. [latex] \therefore f(t) [/latex] cannot have two distinct local minima.

options.A: [latex] f(t) [/latex] has at least one local minimum.
options.B: [latex] f(t) [/latex] cannot have two distinct local minima.
options.C: [latex] f(t) [/latex] has at least one local maximum.
options.D: The minimum value of [latex] f(t) [/latex] cannot be negative.

question: Question 38 Two passive two-port network [latex] P [/latex] and [latex] Q [/latex] are connected as shown in the figure. The impedance matrix of network [latex] P [/latex] is [latex] Z_{P}=\left[\begin{array}{cc}40 \Omega & 60 \Omega \\ 80 \Omega & 100 \Omega\end{array}\right] [/latex]. The admittance matrix of network [latex] Q [/latex] is [latex] Y_{Q}=\left[\begin{array}{cc}5 S & -2.5 S \\ -2.5 S & 1 S\end{array}\right] [/latex]. Let the [latex] A B C D [/latex] matrix of the two-port network [latex] R [/latex] in the figure be [latex] \left[\begin{array}{ll}\alpha & \beta \\ \gamma & \delta\end{array}\right] [/latex]. The value of [latex] \beta [/latex] in [latex] \Omega [/latex] is _______ (rounded off to 2 decimal places)

Question 39 For the circuit shown in the figure, the source frequency is [latex] 5000 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{sec} [/latex]. The mutual inductance between the magnetically coupled inductors is [latex] 5 \mathrm{mH} [/latex] with their self inductances being [latex] 125 \mathrm{mH} [/latex] and [latex] 1 \mathrm{mH} [/latex]. The Thevenin's impedance. [latex] Z_{\mathrm{th}} [/latex], between the terminals [latex] P [/latex] and [latex] Q [/latex] in [latex] \Omega [/latex] is _____ (rounded off to 2 decimal places).

Question 40 In the circuit shown, [latex] Z_{1}=50 \angle-90^{\circ} [/latex] and [latex] Z_{2}=200 \angle-30^{\circ} \Omega [/latex]. It is supplied by a three phase [latex] 400 \mathrm{~V} [/latex] source with the phase sequence being R-Y-B. Assume the watt meters [latex] W_{1} [/latex] and [latex] W_{2} [/latex] to be ideal. The magnitude of the difference between the readings of [latex] W_{1} [/latex] and [latex] W_{2} [/latex] in watts is ______ (rounded off to 2 decimal places).
solution:
[latex]
\begin{aligned}
V_{R Y} & =400 \angle 0^{\circ} \\
V_{Y B} & =400 \angle-120^{\circ} \\
V_{B R} & =400 \angle-240^{\circ} \\
V_{P C} & =V_{R B}=400 \angle-60^{\circ} \\
I_{1} & =\frac{V_{R B}}{Z_{1}}=\frac{400 \angle-60^{\circ}}{50 \angle-90^{\circ}}=8 \angle 30^{\circ} \\
I_{2} & =\frac{V_{R Y}}{Z_{2}}=\frac{400 \angle 0^{\circ}}{200 \angle-30^{\circ}}=2 \angle 30^{\circ} \Rightarrow I_{C C(2)} \\
I_{L 1} & =I_{C C(1)}=I_{1}+I_{2}=8 \angle 30^{\circ}+2 \angle 30^{\circ} \\
& =10 \angle 30^{\circ} \Rightarrow I_{C C(1)} \\
W & =V_{R B} \times I_{2 \theta} \cos \left(\angle V_{R B} \text { and } I_{L O}\right) \\
W_{1} & =400 \times 10 \times \cos \left(-60^{\circ}-30^{\circ}\right)=0 \text { Watt } \\
W_{2} & =V_{Y B} \times I_{2} \cos \left(\angle V_{Y B} \text { and } I_{2}\right) \\
& =400 \times 2 \times \cos \left(-120^{\circ}-30^{\circ}\right)=-692.8 \text { Watt } \\
W_{2} & =0-(-692.8)=692.8 \text { Watt }
\end{aligned}
 [/latex]

question: Question 41 In the [latex] (x, y, z) [/latex] coordinate system, three point-charges [latex] Q, Q [/latex] and [latex] \alpha Q [/latex] are located in free space at [latex] (-1,0,0),(1,0,0) [/latex] and [latex] (0,-1,0) [/latex] respectively. The value of [latex] \alpha [/latex] for the electric field to be zero at [latex] (0,0.5,0) [/latex] is _____ (rounded off to 1 decimal places).
solution:
From the figure, [latex]
\left.\bar{E}_{n e t}=\bar{E}_{1 y}+\bar{E}_{2 y}+\bar{E}_{\alpha Q}=0 \text { [as per question }\right]
 [/latex] Here, [latex]
\bar{E}_{1 y}=\bar{E}_{2 y}=\bar{E}_{Q} \text { (say) }
 [/latex] [latex] \therefore \quad \bar{E}_{n e t}=\left.2 E\right|_{Q}+\left.2 E\right|_{\alpha Q}=0 [/latex] Now, [latex]
\left.\bar{E}\right|_{Q}=\frac{k Q}{\left[\sqrt{1+0.5^{2}}\right]^{2}} \sin \theta \hat{a}_{y} ; \quad k=\frac{1}{4 \pi \epsilon_{o}}
 [/latex] [latex] \left.\Rightarrow \quad \bar{E}\right|_{Q}=\frac{k Q}{1.25} \times \frac{0.5}{\sqrt{1+0.5^{2}}} \hat{a}_{y}=0.357 k Q \hat{a}_{y} [/latex] Also, [latex] \left.\quad \bar{E}\right|_{\alpha Q}=\frac{k(\alpha Q)}{(1.5)^{2}} \hat{a}_{y}=0.444 k(\alpha Q) \hat{a}_{y} [/latex] Hence, [latex] \quad \bar{E}_{n e t}=2 \times 0.357 k Q \hat{a}_{y}+0.444 k(\alpha Q) \hat{a}_{y}=0 [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \quad 0.715 \mathrm{kQ}=-0.444 \mathrm{k}(\alpha Q) [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \quad \alpha=\frac{-0.715}{0.444}=-1.61 [/latex] [latex] \therefore \quad \alpha=-1.61 [/latex]

question:
Question 42 The given equation represents a magnetic field strength [latex] \bar{H}(r, \theta, \phi) [/latex] in the spherical coordinate system, in free space. Here, [latex] \hat{r} [/latex] and [latex] \hat{\theta} [/latex] represent the unit vectors along [latex] r [/latex] and [latex] \theta [/latex], respectively. The value of [latex] P [/latex] in the equation should be _____ (rounded off to the nearest integer). [latex]
\bar{H}(r, \theta, \phi)=\frac{1}{r^{3}}(\hat{r} P \cos \theta+\hat{\theta} \sin \theta)
 [/latex]

Question 43 If the energy of a continuous-time signal [latex] x(t) [/latex] is [latex] E [/latex] and the energy of the signal [latex] 2 x(2 t-1) [/latex] is [latex] c E [/latex], then [latex] c [/latex] is ______ (rounded off to 1 decimal place).
solution:
[latex]
\begin{aligned}
x(t) & \rightarrow E \text { (energy) } \\
x(t-1) & \rightarrow E \\
x(2 t-1) & \rightarrow \frac{E}{2} \\
2 x(2 t-1) & \rightarrow(2)^{2}(E / 2)=2 E=C E \\
C & =2
\end{aligned}
 [/latex]

question:
Question 44 A 3-phase star connected slip ring induction motor has the following parameters referred to the stator: [latex]
R_{s}=3 \Omega,  X_{s}=2 \Omega, X_{r}^{\prime}=2 \Omega,  R_{r}^{\prime}=2.5 \Omega,
 [/latex] The per phase stator to rotor effective turns ratio is [latex] 3: 1 [/latex]. The rotor winding is also star connected. The magnetizing reactance and core loss of the motor can be neglected. To have maximum torque at starting, the value of the extra resistance in ohms (referred to the rotor side) to be connected in series with each phase of the rotor winding is _____ (rounded off to 2 decimal places).
solution:
Condition for the maximum torque [latex]
\frac{R_{2}^{\prime}}{s}=\sqrt{3^{2}+4^{2}}=5
 [/latex] Substituting, s=1 As maximum torque at starting [latex]
\begin{aligned}
R_{2}^{\prime}+R_{e x t}^{\prime} & =5 \\
R_{e x t}^{\prime} & =5-2.5=2.5 \Omega \\
\frac{2.5}{3^{2}} & =0.277 \Omega
\end{aligned}
 [/latex]

question: Question 45 A [latex] 5 \mathrm{~kW} [/latex]. [latex] 220 \mathrm{~V} [/latex] DC shunt motor has [latex] 0.5 \Omega [/latex] armature resistance including brushes. The motor draws a no-load current of [latex] 3 \mathrm{~A} [/latex]. The field current is constant at [latex] 1 \mathrm{~A} [/latex]. Assuming that the core and rotational losses are constant and independent of the load, the current (in amperes) drawn by the motor while delivering the rated load, for the best possible efficiency, is _____ (rounded off to 2 decimal places).

Question 46 The single line diagram of a lossless system is shown in the figure. The system is operating in steady-state at a stable equilibrium point with the power output of the generator being [latex] P_{\max } \sin \delta [/latex]. where [latex] \delta [/latex] is the load angle and the mechanical power input is [latex] 0.5 P_{\max } [/latex]. A fault occurs on line 2 such that the power output of the generator is less than 0.5. [latex] P_{\max } [/latex] during the fault. After the fault is cleared by opening line 2. The power output of the generator is [latex] \left\{P_{\max } / \sqrt{2}\right\} \sin \delta [/latex]. If the critical fault clearing angle is [latex] \pi / 2 [/latex] radians, the accelerating area on the power angle carve is ______ times [latex] P_{\max } [/latex] (rounded off to 2 decimal places)

Question 47 Consider the closed-loop system shown in the figure with [latex] G(s)=\frac{K\left(s^{2}-2 s+2\right)}{\left(s^{2}+2 s+5\right)} [/latex]. The root locus for the closed-loop system is to be drawn for [latex] 0 \leq K \\lt \infty [/latex]. The angle of departure (between [latex] 0^{\circ} [/latex] and [latex] 360^{\circ} [/latex] ) of the root locus branch drawn from the pole [latex] (-1+j 2) [/latex], in degree, is ______ (rounded off to the nearest integer).

Question 48 Consider the stable closed-loop system shown in the figure. The asymptotic Bode magnitude plot of [latex] G(s) [/latex] has a constant slope of [latex] -20 \mathrm{~dB} / [/latex] decade at least till [latex] 100 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{sec} [/latex] with the gain crossover frequency being [latex] 10 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{sec} [/latex]. Hie asymptotic Bode phase plot remains constant at [latex] -90^{\circ} [/latex] at least till [latex] \omega=10 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{sec} [/latex]. The steady-state error of the closed-loop system for a unit ramp input is _____ (rounded off to 2 decimal places).
solution:
Initial slppe [latex] =-20 \mathrm{~dB} / \mathrm{sec} [/latex] Open loop transfer function [latex] =\frac{k}{s} [/latex] [latex]
\begin{aligned}
20 \log _{10} k & =20 \\
k & =10
\end{aligned}
 [/latex] [latex] e_{s s} [/latex] for type -1 system for ramp input [latex]
e_{s S}=\frac{1}{k_{v}}=\frac{1}{10}=0.1
 [/latex]

question:
Question 49 Consider the stable closed-loop system shown in the figure. The magnitude and phase values of the frequency response of [latex] G(s) [/latex] are given in the table. The value of the gain [latex] K_{1}( > 0) [/latex] for a [latex] 50^{\circ} [/latex] phase margin is (rounded off to 2 decimal places). [latex]
\begin{array}{|c|c|c|}
\hline
 \omega  \text{ in rad/sec} & \text{Magnitude in dB}  & \text{Phase in degrees} \\
\hline
0.5 & -7 & -40 \\
\hline
1.0 & -10 & -80 \\
\hline
2.0 & -18 & -130 \\
\hline
10.0 & -40 & -200 \\
\hline
\end{array}
[/latex]
solution:
[latex]
\begin{aligned}
& R(s) \longrightarrow \bigcap_{-}^{+} \frac{K_{I}}{s} \longrightarrow G(s) \longrightarrow C(s) \\
& G H(s)=\frac{K_{I}}{s} G(s) \\
& \mathrm{PM}=180^{\circ}+\angle G H(j \omega)_{\omega_{g c}}=50^{\circ} \\
& \Rightarrow \quad 180^{\circ}+\left[-90^{\circ}+\angle G(j \omega)\right]_{\omega_{g c}}=50^{\circ} \\
& \therefore \quad \angle G(j \omega)=-40^{\circ} \\
& \text { at } \omega_{\mathrm{gc}} \Rightarrow \quad|G H(j \omega)|=0 \mathrm{~dB} \\
& |G(j \omega)|=-7 \mathrm{~dB} \text { and } \angle G(j \omega)=-40^{\circ} \\
& \therefore \quad\left|\frac{K_{I}}{s}\right|_{\omega=0.5}=+7 \mathrm{~dB} \\
& \begin{array}{ll}
\therefore & \frac{K_{I}}{0.5}=2.24 \\
\therefore & K_{I}=1.12
\end{array}
\end{aligned}
 [/latex]

The ratio of the rms value of the fundamental component of the input current to the rms value of the total input current of the bridge is ______ (rounded off to 3 decimal places).

The fundamental frequency of the output voltage is [latex] 50 \mathrm{~Hz} [/latex]. If the DC input voltage of the inverter is [latex] 100 \mathrm{~V} [/latex] and the value of the load inductance is [latex] 20 \mathrm{mH} [/latex], the peak-to-peak load current in amperes is ______ (rounded off to the nearest integer).

For example, the decimal number [latex] 12\left(=1 \times 10^{1}+2 \times 10^{0}\right) [/latex] is expressed as [latex] 14\left(=1 \times 8^{1}+4 \times 8^{0}\right) [/latex] in the octal number system. The decimal number 108 in the octal number system is

Question 59 A shopkeeper buys shirts from a producer and sells them at [latex] 20 \% [/latex] profit. A customer has to pay ₹ [latex] 3,186.00 [/latex] including [latex] 18 \% [/latex] taxes, per shirt. At what price did the shopkeeper buy each shirt from the producer?
solution:
[latex]
\begin{aligned}
x \times \frac{120}{100} \times \frac{118}{100} & =3186 \\
x & =\frac{100 \times 100 \times 3186}{120 \times 118} \\
x & =2250
\end{aligned}
 [/latex]

Question 61 In the given text, the blanks are numbered (i)-(iv). Select the best match for all the blanks. Following a row __(i)__ the shopkeeper __(ii)__ the price of a frying pan, the cook stood __(iii)__ a row to withdraw cash __(iv)__ the ATM booth.

Question 63 The chart below shows the data of the number of cars bought by Millennials and Gen [latex] \mathrm{X} [/latex] people in a country from the year 2010 to 2020 as well as the yearly fuel consumption of the country (in Million liters). Considering the data presented in the chart, which one of the following options is true?

options.A: The percentage increase in fuel consumption from 2010 to 2015 is more than the percentage increase in fuel consumption from 2015 to 2020.
options.B: The increase in the number of Millennial car buyers from 2015 to 2020 is less than the decrease in the number of Gen X car buyers from 2010 to 2015.
options.C: The increase in the number of Millennial car buyers from 2010 to 2015 is more than the decrease in the number of Gen X car buyers from 2010 to 2015.
options.D: The decrease in the number of Gen X car buyers from 2015 to 2020 is more than the increase in the number of Millennial car buyers from 2010 to 2015.

question:
Question 64 The assembly shown below has three teethed circular objects (Pinions) and two
teethed flat objects (Racks), which are perfectly mating with each other. Pinions can
only rotate clockwise or anti-clockwise staying at its own center. Racks can
translate towards the left ([latex] \leftarrow [/latex]) or the right ([latex] \rightarrow [/latex]) direction. If the object A (Rack) is translating towards the right ([latex] \rightarrow [/latex]) direction, the correct
statement among the following is

options.A: Object B translates towards the right direction.
options.B: Object B translates towards the left direction.
options.C: Object R rotates in the anticlockwise direction.
options.D: Object Q rotates in the clockwise direction.

question: Question 65 A surveyor has to measure the horizontal distance from her position to a distant reference point C. Using her position as the center, a [latex] 200 \mathrm{~m} [/latex] horizontal line segment is drawn with the two endpoints [latex] A [/latex] and [latex] B [/latex]. Points [latex] A, B [/latex] and [latex] C [/latex] are not collinear. Each of the angles [latex] \angle C A B [/latex] and [latex] \angle \mathrm{CBA} [/latex] are measured as [latex] 87.8^{\circ} [/latex]. The distance (in [latex] \mathrm{m} [/latex] ) of the reference point [latex] \mathrm{C} [/latex] from her position is nearest to
solution: [latex] \tan \theta=\frac{C x}{A x} [/latex] [latex] \tan 87.8=\frac{C x}{100} [/latex] [latex] C x=100 \times \tan 87.8 [/latex] [latex] =2603 [/latex]
